availability.p: Note that the CC licence only applies to the XML file. Users should also cite the original source of the text.

sourceDesc.bibl: Marlett, Stephen A. (2022): Words from Another World. A Collection of Analyzed Seri Texts. Oaxaca: Instituto Lingüístico de Verano. Quot. pp. 142-152.

projectDesc.p: Text digitized and encoded for use in the Forager Folklore Database. The FFDB offers a basis for a systematic study of narrative universals, the evolutionary origin of storytelling, and (comparative) folklore studies.

samplingDecl.p: The narrative was selected for being a genuine piece of oral literature recorded directly, or mediated by an interpreter, from a narrator who either lived or grew up as a member of a culture whose subsistence at the time of recording was, or until recently had been, depending primarily on hunting, gathering, and/or fishing. Care was taken to ensure the quality of the recording and the relative absence of external cultural influences.

namespace.tagUsage: Used to mark personal names (usually characters).

Referencing strings are used to mark up animal names, plant names, and colors. The type attribute correspondingly takes one of the following values: animal
animal nameplant
plant namecolor
color adjective or noun

Used to mark shifts towards a metatextual level or back to the diegesis. The feature attributes takes one of the following values: anamyth
Shift to a framing metacommentary at the beginning of a narrative.apartmyth
Shift to a comment or aside within the course of a narration.epimyth
Shift to a framing metacommentary at the end of a narrative.diegesis
Shift back to the diegesis of the tale.

prefixDef.p: Private URIs using the p prefix are pointers to person elements in the personography.xml file.
URIs using the q prefix are Wikidata Q identifiers and refer to the respective entries on Wikidata.
Private URIs using the g prefix are pointers to the respective lemmas in the FFDB collection of glossaries.

editorialDecl.p: Footnotes are generally retained, but no effort has been made to link the narratives mentioned in comparative notes with corresponding records within the FFDB.
Page numbers have been retained, but page beginnings, pb, occurring within a word have been moved either before or after the word (or nominal phrase) on a case to case basis, without general rule.

normalization.p: Omissions as well as supplementations by the original editor are set in brackets. In all other cases, parentheses in the original are retained.
Latin passages in the original (usually to mask language and themes deemed indecent) are rendered in English.

hyphenation.p: End-of-line hyphenation has been removed. All other hyphenation has been retained.

quotation.p: All quotation marks have been retained. No effort was made to mark up passages in quotation marks as, for example, q, quote, said, cit, or soCalled.

body.p: The young giant was a male, an orphan, it is said. He was bad off in every way: he had no possessions, no place to live, and no food. He wandered around like an animal rather than like a person. That's how he was. It's not known why, but that young giant grew a bit older and was a young man. During that time, he had seven wives. He treated each one as if she were his only wife. And so they were there. But then, the Catastrophe happened and everything in the world changed. Everything turned into something else. When the Catastrophe was over, the rainbow was there. The different colors are the women who were the young giant's wives, and one color is on top of the rest. That one is the young giant. The other ones are all his wives. The different colors are there, it is said. Nothing very surprising happened.In the recording, one can hear a bit more material between this sentence and the next. It was not included in the published version of Herrera (1976b). This has not been transcribed or recorded. The young giant lacked possessions and did not have a good life, but he had seven wives. The Catastrophe happened, and from that point on his wives were the rainbow. That's the end of the story.
